game_engine module

game_engine.attack(coordinates: tuple[int, int], board: list[list[str | None]], battleships: dict[str, int]) → bool[source]

Returns if attack hits a ship and updates the board and ship counters

If the target coordinate is already None, the attack is a miss. If the attack hits, it reverts the target coordinate to None, then, the corresponding ship counter in the dictionary will decrement by 1.

Parameters:

  • coordinates (Coordinates) – Coordinates of the attack

  • board (Board) – Board to target and modify

  • battleships (dict[str, int]) – Dictionary of ships and its corresponding lengths

Returns:

Success or failure of the attack

Return type:

bool

game_engine.cli_coordinates_input(board_size: int = 10) → tuple[int, int][source]

Prompts the user for a valid coordinate input through the command-line

Parameters:

board_size (int, optional) – Size of board for range validation check, defaults to 10

Returns:

Tuple pair of int representing x and y coordinates

Return type:

Coordinates

game_engine.print_board(board: list[list[str | None]], show_acronym: bool = True) → None[source]

Prints an ASCII representation of the board’s state

If show_acronym is True, each cell with a ship will be represented with the first two characters of the ship name. Mainly for debugging. If show_acronym is False, each cell with a ship will be represented as ## Any unoccupied cells will be represented as ::

Parameters:

  • board (Board) – Board to display

  • show_acronym (bool, optional) – Represent occupied cells with 2 character ship name acronyms, defaults to True

game_engine.simple_game_loop() → None[source]

Simple game loop with one player, one board and ships always revealed
